Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Novel Heme Chemistry of Cytochrome c'

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
In many processes vital for life (e.g. respiration, gas sensing/signaling, and toxicity defense) heme proteins must bind a specific diatomic gas, e.g. oxygen (O2), carbon monoxide (CO), or nitric oxide (NO). To modulate heme reactivity (and achieve a selective gas response), proteins utilize the structural and chemical properties of the heme pocket environments. A major goal of this project is to investigate how the spatial environments of heme iron sites can dramatically affect their reactivity with gases. This knowledge is important for understanding fundamental biochemical reactions in animals, plants, and bacteria, as well as for the rational design of heme-gas sensors with unique properties. Undergraduate research is an integral part of the project, providing students and local high-school teachers with stimulating experiences and motivation for future scientific endeavors.

The project will focus on the novel heme reactivity of bacterial cytochromes c' in which steric constraints significantly disfavor the distal coordination of O2, CO, and NO, while promoting an unusual distal to proximal heme-NO conversion. The coordination of NO at both heme faces (distal and proximal) represents a new type of heme protein reactivity that may be relevant to the proposed NO-binding function(s) of cytochromes c', as well as to NO-selective responses in gas-sensing proteins. By characterizing distal pocket variants of Alcaligenes xylosoxidans cytochrome c' (AXCP), as well as other cytochromes c', the overall goal is to define the connection between distal steric constraints, structural perturbations, and heme reactivity, including distal vs proximal NO coordination. A "loaded spring" hypothesis will be tested in which steric clashes between the crowded distal pocket and diatomic gas (XO) ligands lead to structurally perturbed high-energy heme-XO complexes with altered reactivity. The project will utilize spectroscopy (UV-visible absorption, resonance Raman, and Electron Paramagnetic Resonance), kinetics (stopped-flow and flash photolysis) and other techniques (X-ray crystallography and potentiometry) to study wild-type and variant cytochrome c' reactivity as function of distal steric bulk and gas identity. Undergraduates and high school teachers will receive training in these techniques and be involved in interpreting the results.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In many life processes (e.g. respiration, gas sensing/signaling, and toxicity defense) iron-containing sites of heme proteins must bind a specific diatomic gas (NO, CO, or O2). A major goal of this project was to investigate how the spatial environments of heme iron sites can dramatically affect their reactivity with gases. This project focused on bacterial heme proteins, cytochromes c’-α, which exhibit the unusual ability of binding NO to either the distal or proximal heme face. Our integrated use of spectroscopy, X-ray crystallography, site-directed mutagenesis, and kinetics provided a detailed picture of how steric constraints in cytochromes c’-α promote distal to proximal heme-NO conversion. Our data support a novel “balance of affinities” mechanism in which steric constraints at the distal heme site promote distal to proximal heme-NO conversion by favoring the release of distal NO from a dinitrosyl precursor. This knowledge is important for understanding fundamental biochemical reactions in animals, plants, and bacteria, as well as for the rational design of heme-gas sensors with unique properties. We also found that removal of steric hindrance at the distal site of Alcaligenes xylosoxidans cytochrome c’-α (AxCP-α) allows nitrite (NO2-) to bind to the heme iron. Nitrite binding to heme proteins is important for the anaerobic production of the cellular signaling molecule, NO.  Using vibrational spectroscopy and density functional theory, we demonstrated that nitrite binds to AxCP-a via the N- (rather than an O-) atom. Establishing which atom of nitrite binds to the heme iron is important for elucidating mechanisms of nitrite to NO conversion.

Preliminary structural and spectroscopic data was also obtained for two homologous (but functionally distinct) β-sheet heme proteins from Methylococcus capsulatus (Bath): the hydroxylamine oxidizing cytochrome P460 (McP460) and the NO-binding cytochrome c’-β (McCP-β). Bioinformatics analysis suggests that McCP-β may have evolved from McP460 following a gene duplication event. The crystal structures of these proteins reveal very similar protein folds (consistent with an evolutionary link), but very different distal heme pockets. This information may be useful for synthetic biology and rational enzyme design for biotechnology.

As a “Research in Undergraduate Institutions” (RUI) award, this project provided exceptional opportunities for 12 undergraduate students at Eastern Oregon University (EOU) – a small, public liberal arts college in a remote, rural part of the state – to be engaged in cutting-edge research. Using research facilities in the PI’s laboratory, students investigated heme protein reactivity using stopped-flow kinetics and optical absorption spectroscopy. Additional research visits to Oregon Health & Science University and the University of Essex, UK, provided students with additional experience as well as valuable insights into graduate research environments. Students published their results in high-impact peer-reviewed journals, and presented their results at national meetings of the American Chemical Society.
